content.description: This has less-than-vertical face climbing with many holds of all sizes and integrity.  Choose wisely (good alpine training).  This route was down-graded during the first ascent.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a ring bolt and chain.  Your belayer needs a helmet.
content.location: It is on the lower section of the main wall with the lowest angle terrain.

content.description: This THE historical top-rope route of the crag!  A classic. It was trundled and retro-bolted in 2011.  This is the leftmost route in the belay gully on a dead vertical face.  Start up a left-trending ramp for several bolts, get over some big ledge syndrome, and step out right and up to a face crux.  Pull through some juggy, airy overhangs up high.  Slap a hand over the very top of the dike near a resilient pinyon and clip the anchor.
content.protection: A dozen bolts to a ring anchor, backed up to a tree.  A HELMET!  It's very easy to set a top-rope, but be careful on the hike up so avoid knocking rocks on others below!
content.location: This is the leftmost route in the belay gully.  Look for  a left-trending ramp-dihedral.  It is directly under the tree at the top of the crag.

content.description:
This is a slightly overhanging face climb with a few thin moves down low and lots of air up high.  It is the second route from the left end of the belay gully, just right of

Sam's Spam

.
content.protection: Ten stainless bolts to 2 ring anchors. A HELMET, especially for the belayer.
content.location: This is the second route from the far left uphill end of the belay gully.  Look for a bolt line up a clean face one route right of the pinyon at the top of the crag.

content.description: This is a relatively new route on the wall. Expect to encounter loose blocks.
content.location: It is the 6th bolted line counted from left to right.

climbs.name: Mac Attack!
climbs.fa: Matt Hepp, Chris Jackson, Ruth Stewart

content.description:
This line is a littler spicier and a little spookier than

Roger's Ride

.  A steep, thin start leads to a hollow section 1/2 way up, then awesome steep jugs to the anchor.  It's possible to top rope this route via a directional from the anchors of

Roger's Ride

.
content.location: This is the 3rd route from the left in the belay gully.

content.description: Climb delicately past 9 bolts to a sheltered two bolt anchor. A good bit of rock was excavated while installing this route. There is likely more loose rock that will exfoliate with increasing traffic.
content.location: This is the fourth bolted line from the left end of the cliff.

content.description: This has great face climbing on just less than vertical rock that gets slightly harder as you climb higher.  It has a cool position with an arching arete that falls away to your left.  Thanks to Amber and Ron from Montrose for donating to the bolt fund to help create this route.
content.protection: 7 bolts to a ring bolt & chain anchor.
content.location: On the lower climber's right portion of the main wall.  There is a crumbling arete just left of the bolt line, in between Hungry Bucket and the Pipeline.

content.description: This is a cool, left-trending route perched on a face between a falling arete on the left and a curling wave dihedral to the right.  Fun climbing and varied climbing on slighty dirty rock that should clean up with traffic.  I trundled LOTS of loose blocks off this one!  It is a steep, slabby face to a bulge then overhanging stem moves.
content.protection: 10 bolts to (2) ring anchors.  The belayer needs a helmet.
content.location: This is about halfway up the main wall just before a boulder in wedged in the gully.  Lower/rap with a 50m rope.
It is the 5th bolted line from the left end.

content.description:
Start by pulling over a fun bulge past a cool cactus (gently enjoy but don't touch), then go up a fun face (crux) to the last bolt and anchor for

Tim's Slim Jims

.  Brownpoint afficionados like myself can easily top-rope this route from

TSJ

.
content.protection: 6 bolts to to a ring anchor and chain.
content.location: This is the rightmost route on the wall. Further exploration of the dike revealed loose blocks and cracks.  You can see daylight all the way though the dike at some points!
